title: Growing Together
description: Reflect on your journey and how you continue to evolve as a couple.

questions.text: What area have we grown most in together?
choices: Our ability to support each other

therapeutic.rationale: Recognizing growth strengthens couples' confidence in their ability to evolve. Communication growth means better understanding; conflict growth means healthier disagreement; intimacy growth means deeper connection; support growth means stronger partnership; understanding growth means knowing each other more deeply. Acknowledging how far you've come reinforces the relationship's resilience.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different perceived growth areas mean you've each noticed different improvements. Share your perspectives—your partner may be unaware of growth you've observed.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared recognition of growth creates mutual pride in your evolution. You've both felt this shift. Celebrate it explicitly.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How has your relationship improved over time? What's different now compared to a year ago? What growth are you most proud of?

questions.text: What's something I've learned about myself through our relationship?
choices: What I really need to feel loved
What kind of partner I want to be

therapeutic.rationale: Relationships are vehicles for self-discovery. Love-needs reveal attachment patterns; conflict-handling reveals coping; vulnerability-capacity reveals trust depth; partner-aspiration reveals values; hidden-parts reveal authentic self. Close relationships function as mirrors, reflecting back parts of ourselves we might not otherwise see.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different self-discoveries mean you've each learned different things through this relationship. Share what you've discovered—it's valuable information about your growth.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared self-discovery suggests the relationship has taught you similar lessons. You've grown in parallel directions.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What have you learned about yourself through this relationship? What do you know now that you didn't know before? What has been surprising?

questions.text: What's an area where I'd like us to keep growing?

therapeutic.rationale: Growth aspirations reveal relationship values and desires. Deeper conversations seek emotional intimacy; playfulness seeks joy; conflict resolution seeks harmony; individual support seeks partnership; intimate connection seeks physical bonding. Naming where you want to grow helps focus relationship development intentionally.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different growth aspirations reveal different relationship priorities. Your partner may want more playfulness while you want deeper talks. Both are valid—make room for each other's growth desires.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared growth aspirations mean you're aligned on where the relationship should develop. Work on this area together with shared purpose.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Where would you like your relationship to grow? What would that look like? What's preventing this growth now?

questions.text: What has loving you taught me about love?
choices: That love is a choice you make daily
That compromise doesn't mean losing myself

therapeutic.rationale: Each relationship teaches us something about love itself. Daily-choice learners understand love as action; vulnerability-learners understand love as openness; compromise-learners understand love as balance; conflict-learners understand love as repair; capacity-learners understand love as expansion. These lessons become wisdom we carry forward.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different love lessons mean this relationship has taught you different truths. Sharing these lessons deepens appreciation for what you've built together.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared love lessons mean you've reached similar understanding through this relationship. You've been taught the same truths by loving each other.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What has this relationship taught you about love? What did you not understand before that you understand now?

questions.text: What do I hope our relationship looks like in five years?

therapeutic.rationale: Long-term vision reveals relationship values and priorities. Intimacy-seekers want deeper connection; adventure-seekers want shared experience; security-seekers want stable foundation; growth-seekers want mutual development; legacy-builders want impact beyond themselves. Sharing future visions helps couples align on direction.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different five-year visions may need discussion—but often these can coexist. Adventure and security aren't mutually exclusive. Talk about how to honor both visions.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared future vision means you're heading in the same direction. This alignment is a significant relationship strength.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you want your relationship to look like in five years? What would make that vision reality? What are you already doing to get there?
